questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the emergency department 1 hour after a sexual assault during which she was penetrated vaginally. After the assailant left, the patient immediately drove to the hospital. She did not call the police or her family because she felt too embarrassed. Her medical and family history are unremarkable. Her immunizations are up-to-date. She appears tearful and startles when the door to the examination room is slammed shut. She is fully oriented and gives consent to proceed with physical examination and documentation of findings in the presence of a chaperone. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 126/92 mm Hg. Physical examination shows several bruises and abrasions on her upper arms and neck. Pelvic examination shows swelling and erythema of the vulva and vagina. There are multiple abrasions of the labia minora and majora with superficial bleeding. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A urine pregnancy test is negative. The physician orders vaginal specimen nucleic acid amplification tests for chlamydia, gonorrhea, and trichomonas, and serum testing for HIV, hepatitis B, and syphilis. The patient receives psychological counseling, and with her consent, the appropriate legal authorities are notified about the incident. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Administer mifepristone and misoprostol 24 hours apart

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Emergency contraception should be offered to all female patients of reproductive age who have experienced sexual assault. However, the combination of an oral progesterone antagonist (e.g., mifepristone) with a prostaglandin analog (e.g., misoprostol) administered 24–48 hours apart is used for elective abortion rather than emergency contraception. Oral emergency contraception medication (i.e., ulipristal acetate, levonorgestrel, Yuzpe regimen) and intrauterine devices are both effective options for emergency contraception. Although IUDs have the highest reported efficacy in emergency contraception, the insertion of an IUD may increase distress in an individual who has experienced sexual assault.

B) INCORRECT:

HIV postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) should be offered to all individuals who present within 72 hours of experiencing a sexual assault involving vaginal penetration. Treatment usually includes a three-drug regimen of tenofovir, emtricitabine, and an integrase inhibitor (e.g., raltegravir, dolutegravir). Although two-drug regimens can be considered when there are concerns about cost or potential toxicity, three-drug regimens are more effective and less likely to result in resistance. Additionally, abacavir is not recommended in any PEP regimen because initial screening for the presence of HLA-B*57:01 is required and would therefore delay therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

HPV vaccination is recommended in all women aged between 9–26 years who have experienced a sexual assault. This patient is 30 years of age and does not require an HPV vaccine at this time. Although HPV catch-up vaccination may be considered in women aged 27–45 years with an unknown HPV immunization status, its benefit in this age group is minimal. A different intervention is more appropriate at this time.

D) INCORRECT:

Hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG) can be considered for postexposure prophylaxis in individuals who have experienced a sexual assault if the patient is not vaccinated and the perpetrator's HBsAg is positive. Fully vaccinated patients do not require HBIG regardless of the perpetrator's HBsAg status (see “HBV PEP following nonoccupational exposure” table).

E) CORRECT:

Empiric antibiotic therapy with ceftriaxone, doxycycline, and metronidazole is indicated for sexually transmitted infection prophylaxis against gonorrhea, chlamydia, and trichomonas in all adults (trichomoniasis prophylaxis only in women) who have experienced a sexual assault. Because many patients who have experienced sexual assault do not return for a follow-up visit, empiric antibiotic therapy should be given at their initial presentation. Patients who do not receive empiric antibiotic therapy should repeat STI screening 1–2 weeks later because initial results are usually negative in previously uninfected patients. Other recommended interventions at the initial presentation include emergency contraception, HIV postexposure prophylaxis, and hepatitis B postexposure prophylaxis depending on the patient's profile (e.g., immunization status, serum testing results). Prophylaxis against herpes simplex virus is not recommended because there is insufficient evidence to support its effectiveness.
questions.hint: Individuals who have experienced sexual assault require active management during their initial presentation to decrease the risk of developing certain diseases.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old female college student reports being sexually assaulted 48 hours ago by a man she met at a party. She recalls forced vaginal penetration and does not believe the assailant used a condom. She states that she does not have bleeding, vaginal discharge, severe pain, or other trauma.
She currently takes oral contraceptives and has no known drug allergies. She has received the complete hepatitis B vaccination series (and is known to be immune) and has also received the human papillomavirus vaccination series.
In addition to referral to a local rape crisis center and counseling on HIV postexposure prophylaxis, which one of the following empiric treatment regimens for sexually transmitted infections should be offered to this woman?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The combination of ceftriaxone and azithromycin would not provide activity against Trichomonas; in addition, current guidelines recommend avoiding azithromycin for empiric treatment in patients in whom gonococcal infection has not been ruled out, because of concerns about increasing azithromycin resistance in Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

B) INCORRECT:

Current guidelines do not recommend empiric treatment for syphilis or herpes simplex virus infection in people who have been sexually assaulted; consequently, neither benzathine penicillin nor acyclovir is warranted in this case. Syphilis is less prevalent than other sexually transmitted infections, and prophylaxis against gonorrhea may also have activity against Treponema pallidum.

C) INCORRECT:

Current guidelines do not recommend empiric treatment for syphilis or herpes simplex virus infection in people who have been sexually assaulted; consequently, neither benzathine penicillin nor acyclovir is warranted in this case. Syphilis is less prevalent than other sexually transmitted infections, and prophylaxis against gonorrhea may also have activity against Treponema pallidum. In addition, current guidelines recommend avoiding azithromycin for empiric treatment in patients in whom gonococcal infection has not been ruled out, because of concerns about increasing azithromycin resistance in Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

D) INCORRECT:

Current guidelines do not recommend empiric treatment for herpes simplex virus infection in people who have been sexually assaulted; consequently, acyclovir is not warranted in this case.

E) CORRECT:

The lifetime prevalence of sexual assault is between 13% and 39% for women; college students and those younger than age 24 are at increased risk. Between 17% and 43% of women who have been sexually assaulted present for medical evaluation after the assault.

The most frequently diagnosed sexually transmitted infections (STIs) in women after sexual assault are trichomoniasis, gonorrhea, and chlamydia. Patients may not have symptoms of these STIs soon after the assault, and testing can yield false-negative results. Therefore, all patients should be offered prophylaxis for these STIs. The combination of ceftriaxone, metronidazole, and doxycycline will treat gonorrhea, trichomoniasis, and chlamydia, respectively.

Current guidelines also recommend the following for women who have been sexually assaulted:

• Hepatitis B vaccination if the patient is not already immunized against hepatitis B virus or is not immune to this infection; hepatitis B immune globulin should also be considered if the patient is unvaccinated and the assailant is known to have hepatitis B infection
• Human papillomavirus vaccination for women aged 9 to 26 years who have not yet been vaccinated (this can be considered up to age 45 based on shared decision-making)
• Levonorgestrel for pregnancy prevention
• Discussion of HIV postexposure prophylaxis

Key learning point: Women who present after forced vaginal penetration should be offered prophylactic antibiotic treatment against infection from Neisseria gonorrhoeae, Chlamydia, and Trichomonas.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old young woman presents to the emergency department 36 hours after a suspected sexual assault. She states that she went to a party with a man that she had communicated with online; she suspects that she was drugged, given that she had only one alcoholic drink but still does not recall any details of the evening until she woke up at the party naked from the waist down. She has no recollection of what occurred, but she did notice pain and bruising in the vaginal area. She is not certain if she has received the hepatitis B vaccine series in the past.
In addition to discussing postexposure prophylaxis for HIV, which one of the following combinations of medications would be most appropriate to offer this patient after a full evaluation?

choices.text: Doxycycline, ceftriaxone, metronidazole, hepatitis B vaccine, and levonorgestrel
Azithromycin, metronidazole, hepatitis B immune globulin, and hepatitis B vaccine
Ceftriaxone, metronidazole, hepatitis B vaccine, levonorgestrel, and tetanus booster
Doxycycline, ceftriaxone, levonorgestrel, and tetanus booster
Azithromycin, ceftriaxone, hepatitis B immune globulin, and levonorgestrel

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Between 13% and 39% of women and 3% of men experience sexual assault in their lifetimes. Populations at higher risk include people with physical or mental disabilities; homeless individuals; gay, lesbian, bisexual, or transgender individuals; people who use alcohol or drugs; college students; and those younger than 24 years of age.

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends that people who have been sexually assaulted be offered first-line prophylactic treatments to prevent the following sexually transmitted infections:

• Gonorrhea : Previous recommendations for dual therapy for gonorrhea (ceftriaxone 250 mg intramuscularly plus azithromycin 1 g by mouth, each in a single dose) have been superseded by updated guidelines that recommend monotherapy with ceftriaxone 500 mg intramuscularly in a single dose.
• Chlamydia : A 7-day course of doxycycline 100 mg by mouth twice daily is the recommended treatment for chlamydia when concurrent gonococcal infection cannot be ruled out, such as after recent sexual assault. (In cases where gonorrhea has been ruled out, a single dose of azithromycin 1 g by mouth is an alternative treatment for confirmed chlamydia, although 7 days of doxycycline by mouth is still preferred.)
• Trichomoniasis : Recommended treatment is metronidazole 500 mg by mouth twice daily for 7 days.
• Hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection : Hepatitis B vaccine is recommended if the patient is not already immunized against HBV or is not immune to this infection. Hepatitis B immune globulin is only recommended if the assailant is known to have HBV infection and the patient has not been fully immunized against HBV.

Human papillomavirus vaccination is also recommended for women ages 9 to 26 years who have not yet been vaccinated (and can be considered up to age 45 based on shared decision-making).

HIV postexposure prophylaxis may be recommended after careful consideration of the assailant’s potential HIV status, the likelihood of transmission, and the toxicities and benefits of treatment.

Pregnancy prevention can be achieved by taking levonorgestrel 1.5 mg in a single dose within 120 hours after unprotected intercourse. Ideally, the drug should be taken within 72 hours, because efficacy decreases gradually as time passes after intercourse.

Key learning point: When a woman presents within 72 hours after a sexual assault by an unknown assailant, the most appropriate medications to offer are doxycycline, ceftriaxone, metronidazole, hepatitis B vaccine, levonorgestrel, and, potentially, HIV postexposure prophylaxis.

B) INCORRECT:

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends that people who have been sexually assaulted be offered first-line prophylactic treatments to prevent the following sexually transmitted infections:

• Gonorrhea : Previous recommendations for dual therapy for gonorrhea (ceftriaxone 250 mg intramuscularly plus azithromycin 1 g by mouth, each in a single dose) have been superseded by updated guidelines that recommend monotherapy with ceftriaxone 500 mg intramuscularly in a single dose.
• Chlamydia : A 7-day course of doxycycline 100 mg by mouth twice daily is the recommended treatment for chlamydia when concurrent gonococcal infection cannot be ruled out, such as after recent sexual assault. (In cases where gonorrhea has been ruled out, a single dose of azithromycin 1 g by mouth is an alternative treatment for confirmed chlamydia, although 7 days of doxycycline by mouth is still preferred.)
• Trichomoniasis : Recommended treatment is metronidazole 500 mg by mouth twice daily for 7 days.
• Hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection : Hepatitis B vaccine is recommended if the patient is not already immunized against HBV or is not immune to this infection. Hepatitis B immune globulin is only recommended if the assailant is known to have HBV infection and the patient has not been fully immunized against HBV.

C) INCORRECT:

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends that people who have been sexually assaulted be offered first-line prophylactic treatments to prevent the following sexually transmitted infections:

• Gonorrhea : Previous recommendations for dual therapy for gonorrhea (ceftriaxone 250 mg intramuscularly plus azithromycin 1 g by mouth, each in a single dose) have been superseded by updated guidelines that recommend monotherapy with ceftriaxone 500 mg intramuscularly in a single dose.
• Chlamydia : A 7-day course of doxycycline 100 mg by mouth twice daily is the recommended treatment for chlamydia when concurrent gonococcal infection cannot be ruled out, such as after recent sexual assault. (In cases where gonorrhea has been ruled out, a single dose of azithromycin 1 g by mouth is an alternative treatment for confirmed chlamydia, although 7 days of doxycycline by mouth is still preferred.)
• Trichomoniasis : Recommended treatment is metronidazole 500 mg by mouth twice daily for 7 days.
• Hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection : Hepatitis B vaccine is recommended if the patient is not already immunized against HBV or is not immune to this infection. Hepatitis B immune globulin is only recommended if the assailant is known to have HBV infection and the patient has not been fully immunized against HBV.

Pregnancy prevention can be achieved by taking levonorgestrel 1.5 mg in a single dose within 120 hours after unprotected intercourse. Ideally, the drug should be taken within 72 hours, because efficacy decreases gradually as time passes after intercourse.

A tetanus booster is not a recommended component of infection prophylaxis following sexual assault.

D) INCORRECT:

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends that people who have been sexually assaulted be offered first-line prophylactic treatments to prevent the following sexually transmitted infections:

• Gonorrhea : Previous recommendations for dual therapy for gonorrhea (ceftriaxone 250 mg intramuscularly plus azithromycin 1 g by mouth, each in a single dose) have been superseded by updated guidelines that recommend monotherapy with ceftriaxone 500 mg intramuscularly in a single dose.
• Chlamydia : A 7-day course of doxycycline 100 mg by mouth twice daily is the recommended treatment for chlamydia when concurrent gonococcal infection cannot be ruled out, such as after recent sexual assault. (In cases where gonorrhea has been ruled out, a single dose of azithromycin 1 g by mouth is an alternative treatment for confirmed chlamydia, although 7 days of doxycycline by mouth is still preferred.)
• Trichomoniasis : Recommended treatment is metronidazole 500 mg by mouth twice daily for 7 days.
• Hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection : Hepatitis B vaccine is recommended if the patient is not already immunized against HBV or is not immune to this infection. Hepatitis B immune globulin is only recommended if the assailant is known to have HBV infection and the patient has not been fully immunized against HBV.

Pregnancy prevention can be achieved by taking levonorgestrel 1.5 mg in a single dose within 120 hours after unprotected intercourse. Ideally, the drug should be taken within 72 hours, because efficacy decreases gradually as time passes after intercourse.

A tetanus booster is not a recommended component of infection prophylaxis following sexual assault.

E) INCORRECT:

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends that people who have been sexually assaulted be offered first-line prophylactic treatments to prevent the following sexually transmitted infections:

• Gonorrhea : Previous recommendations for dual therapy for gonorrhea (ceftriaxone 250 mg intramuscularly plus azithromycin 1 g by mouth, each in a single dose) have been superseded by updated guidelines that recommend monotherapy with ceftriaxone 500 mg intramuscularly in a single dose.
• Chlamydia : A 7-day course of doxycycline 100 mg by mouth twice daily is the recommended treatment for chlamydia when concurrent gonococcal infection cannot be ruled out, such as after recent sexual assault. (In cases where gonorrhea has been ruled out, a single dose of azithromycin 1 g by mouth is an alternative treatment for confirmed chlamydia, although 7 days of doxycycline by mouth is still preferred.)
• Trichomoniasis : Recommended treatment is metronidazole 500 mg by mouth twice daily for 7 days.
• Hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection : Hepatitis B vaccine is recommended if the patient is not already immunized against HBV or is not immune to this infection. Hepatitis B immune globulin is only recommended if the assailant is known to have HBV infection and the patient has not been fully immunized against HBV.

Pregnancy prevention can be achieved by taking levonorgestrel 1.5 mg in a single dose within 120 hours after unprotected intercourse. Ideally, the drug should be taken within 72 hours, because efficacy decreases gradually as time passes after intercourse.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old woman reports a 2-week history of vaginal discharge that she first noticed one week after a sexual assault that involved penile penetration of the vagina but no other orifices. She is otherwise healthy with up-to-date immunizations, and a review of systems is otherwise negative.
A complete physical examination is performed, including pelvic examination, which shows erythema of the vaginal vestibule and scant yellowish discharge at the cervical os. The patient has no cervical motion tenderness. A wet mount of vaginal secretions shows no evidence of bacterial vaginosis, trichomoniasis, or candidiasis.
Urine nucleic acid amplification testing is positive for Chlamydia trachomatis and negative for Neisseria gonorrhoeae.
In addition to testing for HIV and hepatitis B virus infection, testing for which one of the following infections is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Herpes simplex virus (HSV) can be transmitted sexually, but testing is not indicated in the absence of symptoms. HSV is associated with genital and/or oral ulcerated lesions that are usually painful.

B) CORRECT:

This patient has symptoms of a sexually transmitted infection (STI) that was most likely acquired during sexual assault. The following tests are recommended in women who present after sexual assault, whether they are symptomatic or not:

• A wet mount of vaginal secretions with measurement of vaginal pH and potassium hydroxide (KOH) application for an amine odor test to assess for bacterial vaginosis, trichomoniasis, and candidiasis. This testing is particularly important in this patient who presents with vaginal discharge, although the discharge may be from the chlamydial infection.
• Nucleic acid amplification testing for chlamydia and gonorrhea of specimens obtained from sites of attempted or completed penetration.
• Serum sample for serologic testing for HIV, hepatitis B virus (HBV), and syphilis (with a treponemal antibody test). Syphilis and HIV serologic testing should be repeated at 6 weeks and 3 months after the assault, because a test at 2 weeks may be within the serologic window period for detection of a new syphilis or HIV infection.

In addition to undergoing STI screening, patients who have been sexually assaulted can also consider immunization against HPV and HBV and postexposure prophylaxis against HIV infection. In addition, they should be asked about symptoms that would warrant a mental health evaluation, such as symptoms of depression and thoughts of self-harm or suicide. Appropriate referrals and follow-up should be made at the time of STI treatment.

Key learning point: Women who present after a sexual assault should be tested for candidiasis, trichomoniasis, and bacterial vaginosis (with a wet mount of vaginal secretions); gonorrhea and chlamydia (with nucleic acid amplification testing of specimens obtained from sites of penetration); and HIV, hepatitis B virus, and syphilis (with serum samples).

C) INCORRECT:

Hemophilus ducreyi (the organism that causes chancroid, which is characterized by genital ulcers and occasional inguinal lymphadenopathy) can be transmitted sexually, but screening for this pathogen after sexual assault is not recommended in the absence of symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Hepatitis C virus can be transmitted sexually, but screening for this pathogen after sexual assault is not recommended in the absence of symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Human papillomavirus (HPV) can be transmitted sexually, but testing is not indicated in the absence of symptoms. HPV is characterized by the presence of cauliflower-like fleshy growths (concerning for warts) and abnormal findings on cervical cancer screening tests.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old girl reports being sexually assaulted 12 hours ago by an unknown man she met at a party. The incident included vaginal and anal intercourse without protection.
The patient is not using any contraceptives. She has received all recommended childhood vaccines and is immune to hepatitis B.
A urine pregnancy test is negative.
In addition to counseling, referral to a local rape crisis center, pregnancy prophylaxis, and discussion about HIV postexposure prophylaxis, which one of the following prophylactic regimens is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Ceftriaxone once; metronidazole and doxycycline for 7 days

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Trichomoniasis, gonorrhea, and chlamydia are the most frequently diagnosed sexually transmitted infections (STIs) among women who have been sexually assaulted. Prophylactic therapy should therefore include metronidazole or tinidazole for trichomoniasis, ceftriaxone for gonorrhea, and doxycycline for chlamydia. Although previous guidelines recommended azithromycin for prophylaxis against chlamydia, more recent recommendations suggest using doxycycline instead in cases where gonorrhea has not been ruled out, because of concerns about azithromycin resistance in Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

Human papillomavirus vaccination is also recommended for women aged 9 to 26 years who have not yet been vaccinated.

If the patient is not already immunized against hepatitis B virus (HBV) or is not immune to this infection, hepatitis B vaccination should be given as well. Hepatitis B immune globulin can also be considered if the assailant is known to have HBV infection and the patient has not been fully immunized against HBV.

If the patient presents within 72 hours after sexual assault, and the HIV status of the source patient is either positive or unknown, HIV postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) can also be offered. Evidence for the effectiveness of PEP after sexual assault is extrapolated from studies of PEP to reduce maternal-fetal HIV transmission and infection after health care exposures. In these settings, PEP reduces the rate of HIV transmission by 70% to 80%. Although PEP is widely encouraged for people who have been sexually assaulted, many decline it, and many do not complete the recommended 28-day course.

Patients who have been sexually assaulted should have close-follow up, including repeat STI testing one to two weeks after the incident.

Key learning point: In addition to being offered HIV postexposure prophylaxis, women who have been sexually assaulted should receive treatment designed to prevent infection with chlamydia, gonorrhea, and trichomoniasis.

B) INCORRECT:

Metronidazole alone is insufficient after sexual assault because it does not include coverage for chlamydia or gonorrhea.

C) INCORRECT:

Chlamydia is a frequently diagnosed sexually transmitted infection (STI) among women who have been sexually assaulted. Prophylactic therapy should therefore include doxycycline for chlamydia.

D) INCORRECT:

Gonorrhea is a frequently diagnosed sexually transmitted infection (STI) among women who have been sexually assaulted. Prophylactic therapy should therefore include ceftriaxone for gonorrhea.

E) INCORRECT:

Although previous guidelines recommended azithromycin for prophylaxis against chlamydia, more recent recommendations suggest using doxycycline instead in cases where gonorrhea has not been ruled out, because of concerns about azithromycin resistance in Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl reports a 2-month history of vaginal discharge that she first noticed 2 weeks after a sexual assault that involved penile penetration of the vagina but no other orifices. She is otherwise healthy with up-to-date immunizations, and a review of systems is otherwise negative.
A complete physical examination is performed, including pelvic examination, which shows erythema of the vaginal vestibule and scant yellowish discharge at the cervical os. The patient has no cervical motion tenderness. A wet mount of vaginal secretions shows no evidence of bacterial vaginosis, trichomoniasis, or candidiasis.
Urine nucleic acid amplification testing is positive for Chlamydia trachomatis and negative for Neisseria gonorrhoeae.
In addition to testing for HIV and hepatitis B virus infection, testing for which one of the following infections is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient has symptoms of a sexually transmitted infection (STI) that was most likely acquired during sexual assault. The following tests are recommended in women who present after sexual assault, whether they are symptomatic or not:

• A wet mount of vaginal secretions with measurement of vaginal pH and potassium hydroxide (KOH) application for an amine odor test, to assess for bacterial vaginosis, trichomoniasis, and candidiasis. This testing is particularly important in this patient who presents with vaginal discharge, although the discharge may be from the chlamydial infection.
• Nucleic acid amplification testing for chlamydia and gonorrhea of specimens obtained from sites of attempted or completed penetration.
• Serum sample for serologic testing for HIV, hepatitis B virus infection (HBV), and syphilis (with a treponemal antibody test). Syphilis and HIV serologic testing should be repeated at 6 weeks and 3 months after the assault, because a test at 2 weeks may be within the serologic window period for detection of a new syphilis or HIV infection.

In addition to undergoing STI screening, patients who have been sexually assaulted can also consider immunization against HPV and HBV and postexposure prophylaxis against HIV infection. In addition, they should be asked about symptoms that would warrant a mental health evaluation, such as symptoms of depression and thoughts of self-harm or suicide. Appropriate referrals and follow-up should be made at the time of STI treatment.

Key learning point: An adolescent girl who presents after a sexual assault should be tested for candidiasis, trichomoniasis, and bacterial vaginosis (with a wet mount of vaginal secretions); gonorrhea and chlamydia (with nucleic acid amplification testing of specimens obtained from sites of penetration); and HIV, hepatitis B virus, and syphilis (with serum samples).

B) INCORRECT:

Hemophilus ducreyi (the organism that causes chancroid, which is characterized by genital ulcers and occasional inguinal lymphadenopathy) and hepatitis C virus can both be transmitted sexually, but screening for these pathogens after sexual assault is not recommended in the absence of symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Human papillomavirus (HPV) and herpes simplex virus (HSV) can be transmitted sexually, but testing is not indicated in the absence of symptoms. HSV is associated with genital and/or oral ulcerated lesions that are usually painful.

D) INCORRECT:

Hemophilus ducreyi (the organism that causes chancroid, which is characterized by genital ulcers and occasional inguinal lymphadenopathy) and hepatitis C virus can both be transmitted sexually, but screening for these pathogens after sexual assault is not recommended in the absence of symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Human papillomavirus (HPV) and herpes simplex virus (HSV) can be transmitted sexually, but testing is not indicated in the absence of symptoms. HPV is characterized by the presence of cauliflower-like fleshy growths (concerning for warts) and abnormal findings on cervical cancer screening tests.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man comes to the emergency department because he is afraid of having contracted a sexually transmitted disease. During the patient interview in the triage bay, he keeps glancing at other patients and the entrance to the building. After careful and empathetic exploration of the reasons for his fear, he reveals that he was sexually assaulted by a male friend the previous night. He states that his friend penetrated him anally without his consent after they came home from a party. He appears anxious and tears up while speaking. Vital signs are within normal limits. Bruises are seen on the patient's forearms and neck. Which of the following actions should the provider seek the patient's permission for first?

choices.text: Moving the patient to a private examination room
Providing prophylaxis against sexually transmitted infections
Obtaining pertinent information about the sexual assault

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Requesting the patient's permission to report his case to law enforcement authorities may be appropriate at a later point, but it is not the most appropriate action at this time. Sexual assault or abuse of minors must be reported by health care providers (HCPs) to law enforcement or Child Protective Services but, in most states, it is not mandatory for HCPs to report sexual assault of adults to law enforcement authorities.

B) CORRECT:

The approach to survivors of sexual assault in the emergency department differs from other medical emergencies. Physicians must follow a trauma-informed approach to minimize retraumatization by ensuring privacy and obtaining consent for almost every step in management. The patient should be asked if they would like to be brought to a private room and whether the door should be left open or closed. If desired, patients can be accompanied by a friend, relative, or medical chaperone. Subsequently, consent should be obtained for history taking, physical examination, forensic documentation of the injuries and evidence collection, and reporting to law enforcement authorities. Ideally, patients who have experienced sexual assault should be managed by trained professionals such as sexual assault nurse examiners (SANEs) or sexual assault forensic examiners (SAFEs). In most states, there is no legal obligation for the physician to report sexual crimes in adults without the patient's consent. If the patient wishes to report the crime, a forensic examination will be conducted with a sexual assault forensic evaluation kit to gather and preserve the chain of evidence for law enforcement authorities.

Before leaving the setting of care, all patients should be offered testing for sexually transmitted infections (STIs) and adult patients should be offered empiric prophylaxis against certain STIs. A female patient of reproductive age should also be offered pregnancy testing and emergency contraception. In addition, psychological counseling with referrals to sexual assault crisis programs, rape crisis advocates, social workers, and/or psychiatrists (e.g., for trauma-related disorders) should be provided as needed.

Key learning point: After excluding medical emergencies, the first priority in managing sexual assault survivors is to ensure privacy and safety by moving the patient to a private setting before proceeding with further care or information gathering.

C) INCORRECT:

Empiric prophylaxis against certain sexually transmitted infections (e.g., HIV, gonorrhea, chlamydia, trichomoniasis, hepatitis B vaccination if immunization status is unknown or negative) should be offered to adult patients who have been sexually assaulted before they leave the setting of care (e.g., emergency department). However, patients who are medically stable should not receive any medications orally or intravenously until forensic samples have been obtained or if the patient refuses a forensic examination.

D) INCORRECT:

A forensic examination should be offered to all patients who have experienced sexual assault and performed only upon obtaining consent. Evidence is collected with sexual assault forensic evaluation kits, and samples can be collected up to 72 to 120 hours after the assault. Therefore, a forensic examination can be delayed in this case and would not be the most appropriate initial step in management.

E) INCORRECT:

Obtaining pertinent information about details of the sexual assault (e.g., time, type of sexual assault) is required for patient care and can provide important information for the legal prosecution of the perpetrator in the future. However, a trauma-informed approach should be followed with patients who have undergone sexual assault to minimize retraumatization. With this approach, it is important to find an appropriate setting for information gathering and to limit the number of times the patient has to recount the traumatic experience to different people. Gathering information is not the most pressing concern at this time.
questions.hint: In cases of sexual violence, the priority is to ensure that the patient feels safe after life- or limb-threatening emergencies have been excluded.

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl presents with suspected sexual abuse. Examination reveals a fresh hymeneal tear at the 6 o’clock position. What is the most likely explanation for this finding?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A fresh hymeneal tear at the 6 o’clock position is indicative of forceful penile penetration. This area, located at the inferior aspect of the hymenal ring, is particularly susceptible to lacerations from direct, forceful trauma. The tear's well-demarcated edges and inflammatory changes further support this mechanism. Understanding hymenal anatomy and typical injury patterns is essential in evaluating suspected sexual abuse cases.

Key learning point: In cases of suspected sexual abuse, a hymeneal tear at the 6 o'clock position is most suggestive of penile penetration due to the anatomical position and direction of force during penetration.

B) INCORRECT:

Non-specific friction lesions result from repetitive minor trauma, causing superficial abrasions or inflammation. They do not typically present as a fresh, well-defined tear at the 6 o’clock position, which suggests a focused traumatic force rather than diffuse friction.

C) INCORRECT:

Accidental straddle injuries usually result in diffuse trauma to the external genitalia, such as abrasions or contusions, rather than a precise hymeneal tear. The force in straddle injuries is distributed laterally, affecting the labia and perineum, not producing a clean tear at the 6 o’clock position.

D) INCORRECT:

Congenital hymenal variants, such as annular or crescentic hymens, are stable anatomical differences present from birth. They do not present with acute signs of injury, such as a fresh tear or bleeding, which are indicative of trauma.

questions.text: You are seeing a 25-year-old man in the emergency department who is concerned about possible exposure to a sexually transmitted infection. During the triage interview, he appears anxious and frequently glances at other patients and the entrance. After you explore his concerns with care and empathy, he discloses that he was sexually assaulted by a male friend the previous night, involving non-consensual anal penetration after returning from a party. He becomes tearful while speaking. Vital signs are normal. On examination, there are bruises on his forearms and neck. Which one of the following actions should you seek his permission for first?

choices.text: Moving the patient to a private examination room.
Providing prophylaxis against sexually transmitted infections.
Obtaining pertinent information about the sexual assault.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The approach to survivors of sexual assault in the emergency department differs from other medical emergencies. Physicians must follow a trauma-informed approach to minimize retraumatization by ensuring privacy and obtaining consent for almost every step in management. The patient should be asked if they would like to be brought to a private room and whether the door should be left open or closed. If desired, patients can be accompanied by a friend, relative, or medical chaperone. Subsequently, consent should be obtained for history taking, physical examination, forensic documentation of the injuries and evidence collection, and reporting to law enforcement authorities. Ideally, patients who have experienced sexual assault should be managed by trained professionals such as sexual assault nurse examiners (SANEs) or sexual assault forensic examiners (SAFEs). In most states, there is no legal obligation for the physician to report sexual crimes in adults without the patient's consent. If the patient wishes to report the crime, a forensic examination will be conducted with a sexual assault forensic evaluation kit to gather and preserve the chain of evidence for law enforcement authorities.

Before leaving the setting of care, all patients should be offered testing for sexually transmitted infections (STIs) and adult patients should be offered empiric prophylaxis against certain STIs. A female patient of reproductive age should also be offered pregnancy testing and emergency contraception. In addition, psychological counseling with referrals to sexual assault crisis programs, rape crisis advocates, social workers, and/or psychiatrists (e.g., for trauma-related disorders) should be provided as needed.

Key learning point: A trauma-informed approach to sexual assault care prioritizes patient privacy and consent at every step, beginning with offering a private setting before proceeding with history, examination, or interventions.

B) INCORRECT:

Empiric prophylaxis against certain sexually transmitted infections (e.g., HIV, gonorrhea, chlamydia, trichomoniasis, hepatitis B vaccination if immunization status is unknown or negative) should be offered to adult patients who have been sexually assaulted before they leave the setting of care (e.g., emergency department). However, patients who are medically stable should not receive any medications orally or intravenously until forensic samples have been obtained or if the patient refuses a forensic examination.

C) INCORRECT:

Requesting the patient's permission to report his case to law enforcement authorities may be appropriate at a later point, but it is not the most appropriate action at this time. Sexual assault or abuse of minors must be reported by health care providers (HCPs) to law enforcement and the provincial child welfare agency but it is not mandatory for HCPs to report sexual assault of adults.

D) INCORRECT:

A forensic examination should be offered to all patients who have experienced sexual assault and performed only upon obtaining consent. Evidence is collected with sexual assault forensic evaluation kits, and samples can be collected up to 72 to 120 hours after the assault. Therefore, a forensic examination can be delayed in this case and would not be the most appropriate initial step in management.

E) INCORRECT:

Obtaining pertinent information about details of the sexual assault (e.g., time, type of sexual assault) is required for patient care and can provide important information for the legal prosecution of the perpetrator in the future. However, a trauma-informed approach should be followed with patients who have undergone sexual assault to minimize retraumatization. With this approach, it is important to find an appropriate setting for information gathering and to limit the number of times the patient has to recount the traumatic experience to different people. Gathering information is not the most pressing concern at this time.
questions.hint: In cases of sexual violence, the priority is to ensure that the patient feels safe after life- or limb-threatening emergencies have been excluded.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents to the emergency department 3 hours after sexual assault. She reports being strangled and losing consciousness briefly. She appears anxious, has petechial hemorrhages on her face, and complains of throat pain and hoarseness. She requests forensic evidence collection and has not bathed or changed clothes. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain detailed history about the assault for forensic documentation
Collect biological samples while evidence is still present
Obtain head and neck computed tomography angiography to evaluate for vascular injury
Perform primary survey and assess for life-threatening injuries
Begin STI prophylaxis and emergency contraception

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Detailed history taking for forensic documentation is important, but stabilization takes priority. This patient's report of strangulation and loss of consciousness indicates a risk of serious injury that requires immediate medical evaluation.

B) INCORRECT:

Evidence collection is time-sensitive and important, but medical stabilization takes priority over forensic procedures, regardless of the risk for evidence degradation.

C) INCORRECT:

Head and neck computed tomography angiography may be indicated to evaluate for strangulation but should only be performed after the primary survey is completed and the patient is hemodynamically stable.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- The primary survey to identify and treat life-threatening injuries must be performed first, even when forensic evidence collection is time-sensitive. Strangulation can cause delayed complications that require immediate medical assessment and stabilization.

E) INCORRECT:

STI prophylaxis and emergency contraception are important components of care, but they should be initiated after ensuring the patient is hemodynamically stable and does not have life-threatening injuries from the assault.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents to the emergency department 18 hours after an alleged sexual assault. She reports memory gaps and suspects she may have been drugged. Physical examination reveals minor abrasions on her neck and arms. The patient consents to forensic evaluation. During the examination with a sexual assault nurse examiner, dried biological material is noted on the patient's clothing, and the presence of additional evidence is suspected. What is the most appropriate approach to specimen collection at this point?

choices.text: Rehydrate the dried material with a wet swab and then collect with a dry swab
Rehydrate the dried material with sterile saline before collection with a dry swab
Photograph the dried material first, then collect with a moistened swab
Collect the dried material directly with a dry swab and place in evidence container
Use gel-based lubricant to rehydrate the specimen before collection

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- Proper forensic specimen collection is a key component of the sexual assault examination. For dried material, the technique involves first rehydrating the specimen with a wet swab to reconstitute it, followed by collection with a dry swab to maximize sample retrieval while preserving evidence integrity for laboratory analysis.

B) INCORRECT:

Sterile saline is not the appropriate rehydration solution for forensic specimens because it can interfere with laboratory analysis.

C) INCORRECT:

While documentation is important, photographs should be taken after specimen collection, not before. The protocol requires collecting, sealing, and labeling biological specimens first. The areas from which specimens were collected are then photographed to maintain the proper chain of custody.

D) INCORRECT:

Collecting dried material directly with a dry swab may not yield an adequate sample for analysis.

E) INCORRECT:

Gel-based lubricants should never be used in forensic evaluations because they can interfere with DNA analysis and other forensic testing.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents to the emergency department 24 hours after an alleged sexual assault. She consents to forensic evaluation. During the examination, dried biological material is identified on her clothing and what appears to be dried secretions on her inner thigh. The sexual assault nurse examiner asks you about the proper evidence collection technique for these dried samples. What is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Collect directly with a dry swab only
Use a moist swab for collection
Rehydrate with a wet swab, then collect with a dry swab
Scrape material into a plastic container

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Collecting dried material directly with a dry swab alone may not adequately recover the sample and could result in the loss of potentially important forensic evidence. The rehydration step is essential for dried samples.

B) INCORRECT:

Using only a moist swab is insufficient for dried material collection. The standardized protocol requires the two-step wet-then-dry swab technique to ensure proper evidence recovery and maintain chain of custody requirements.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- For dried biological samples, the proper forensic technique requires first rehydrating the material with a wet swab and then collecting it with a dry swab. This two-step process ensures optimal recovery of biological evidence while maintaining sample integrity for forensic analysis.

D) INCORRECT:

Debris should be scraped and collected in a paper bindle, not a plastic container. Additionally, biological samples specifically require the wet-then-dry swab technique rather than scraping methods.

E) INCORRECT:

Documentation alone is inadequate when biological evidence is present. Active collection of biological samples is essential for forensic analysis and potential identification of the perpetrator, especially within the evidence collection window.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman presents to the emergency department 18 hours after a sexual assault. She reports no significant past medical history and is not currently taking any medications. Physical examination shows minor abrasions but no life-threatening injuries. The sexual assault response team has been notified and forensic evaluation is planned. The patient consents to sexually transmitted infection (STI) prophylaxis but declines HIV postexposure prophylaxis. What is the most appropriate empiric antibiotic regimen for this patient?

choices.text: Defer antibiotic prophylaxis until STI testing results are available

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This regimen does not contain ceftriaxone, which is essential for gonorrhea coverage. Gonorrhea prophylaxis is a critical component of empiric STI treatment for adults and adolescents following a sexual assault.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- For all adults and adolescents who have been sexually assaulted, empiric STI prophylaxis includes ceftriaxone for gonorrhea, doxycycline for chlamydia, and metronidazole for women to treat trichomoniasis. This combination addresses the most common STIs resulting from sexual assault.

C) INCORRECT:

Empiric antibiotic prophylaxis is recommended for all adults and adolescents after sexual assault without waiting for test results. Deferring treatment could result in missed opportunities to prevent STI transmission.

D) INCORRECT:

While ceftriaxone appropriately covers gonorrhea, azithromycin is not the preferred agent for chlamydia coverage in STI prophylaxis following sexual assault. Additionally, this regimen does not contain metronidazole for trichomoniasis coverage in women.

E) INCORRECT:

This combination provides adequate coverage for gonorrhea and chlamydia but is incomplete for women, as it does not have metronidazole coverage for trichomoniasis, which is part of the standard empiric regimen.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents to the emergency department 18 hours after a sexual assault. She reports anal penetration by a known assailant whose HIV status is unknown. The patient has no previous hepatitis B vaccination and no known drug allergies. Physical examination shows minor perianal abrasions with dried blood. She is hemodynamically stable. What is the most appropriate step in management?

choices.text: HIV postexposure prophylaxis and hepatitis B vaccine
Hepatitis B vaccine and hepatitis B immune globulin

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient requires both HIV postexposure prophylaxis (due to high-risk sexual contact with anal penetration and mucosal bleeding within 72 hours) and hepatitis B vaccine (as she is unvaccinated). Both should be initiated promptly without waiting for the assailant's test results.

B) INCORRECT:

HIV postexposure prophylaxis alone does not address hepatitis B prevention. Since this patient is unvaccinated against hepatitis B and has had high-risk sexual contact, the hepatitis B vaccine should be administered as part of postexposure prophylaxis.

C) INCORRECT:

Hepatitis B vaccine alone is insufficient for this patient. Given the high-risk sexual contact (anal penetration) with mucosal bleeding within 72 hours of exposure, HIV postexposure prophylaxis should also be initiated based on individual risk factors.

D) INCORRECT:

Deferring prophylaxis is inappropriate because the effectiveness of postexposure prophylaxis decreases significantly with time. HIV postexposure prophylaxis should be initiated within 72 hours, and the hepatitis B vaccine should be given to unvaccinated individuals after sexual assault, regardless of the assailant's status.

E) INCORRECT:

Hepatitis B immune globulin (HBIG) is only indicated when the assailant is known to be HBsAg-positive. Since the assailant's hepatitis B status is unknown, hepatitis B vaccine alone is appropriate for hepatitis B prophylaxis in this unvaccinated patient. If later testing shows the assailant is HBsAg-positive, HBIG should be administered promptly as additional prophylaxis. Furthermore, the hepatitis B vaccine alone is insufficient for this patient because of the high-risk sexual exposure (anal penetration with mucosal bleeding), and HIV postexposure prophylaxis should also be initiated according to an individual risk assessment.
